data.title: Conflict: a Distributed Condition: Contemporary War Ecologies
data.desc:
Conflict is not an exception or an isolated event — it is a constant condition running through society. It is not limited to war or explicit clashes: it emerges within collective life as friction, as a continuous confrontation between competing needs, systems, and visions.
It is not a punctual episode but a latent and distributed condition. It takes on asymmetric, often invisible forms, embedded in cultural practices, social relations, and infrastructures. Its logic is not confined to violence: it also structures coexistence, shaping who holds privilege and who is pushed to the margins.
Exploring distributed conflicts means reading the present as a field where techniques of offense multiply and blur into the infrastructures society depends on. The goal is to generate critical devices, scenarios, and questions that probe the ambiguous nature of conflict as a diffuse condition in a post-territorial age.

data.title: Regulations, legal maps,
data.desc: A legal map refers to a visual and structured representation of legal concepts, laws, or branches of law, similar to a concept map or diagram. It helps simplify and organize the complexity of the legal and bureaucratic system by showing relationships between different rules, institutions, or principles, thus supporting understanding and study. Regulations are specific rules issued by authorities to implement and enforce laws within particular contexts.

data.title: Bureaucracy
data.desc:
Bureaucracy is the body of officials and offices which, organized in various hierarchical levels, carry out the functions of public administration within the state (state bureaucracy; the reform of bureaucracy).
2. In a broader sense, the word refers to the officials of an entity or an organization, even if not state-related.
3. In an abstract, and mostly negative sense, bureaucracy can also refer to the power assumed by the mass of officials, and especially to the long and complex series of formalities and procedures—often perceived as excessive and unnecessary—through which a case must pass to be completed (the slowness, the red tape of bureaucracy).
Finally, in a figurative sense, the term bureaucracy refers to an exaggerated and inflexible observance of regulations, especially when they are followed more in their formal aspects than in their substance.

data.title: Citizen’s life marked by bureaucratic stages
data.desc: A citizen’s life is marked by bureaucratic stages. It begins with birth registration, tax code, health card, and identity documents, and continues with education, applications for scholarships, and certifications. Entering the workforce involves registration with INPS and INAIL, employment notifications, and opening a VAT number. Adulthood brings marriage, buying a house, changing residence, and filing income tax returns. Finally, in old age and at the end of life, one deals with pension applications, death registration, inheritance, and cadastral transfers.

data.title: Rational system
data.desc: Bureaucracy is a rational system designed to maintain order and ensure fairness. It follows structured procedures that must be respected, leaving little room for emotions or personal judgment. By adhering to rules and standardized processes, bureaucracy aims to prevent favoritism and guarantee that decisions are consistent and impartial.

data.title: Il fu Mattia Pascal, 1904, Pirandello
data.desc:
In Il fu Mattia Pascal, Pirandello explores the theme of bureaucratic identity: what happens when a man loses his documents and, with them, his “bureaucratic existence”?

Mattia Pascal, mistakenly believed dead, seizes the chance to reinvent himself as Adriano Meis. However, lacking official documents for this new identity, he discovers that his “freedom” is actually a prison.

Consequences of missing documents:
	•	Legal impossibilities: He cannot marry his love, Adriana, sign contracts, buy property, or defend himself in court. Bureaucracy becomes an impenetrable wall: without certificates, one is nobody.
	•	Social marginalization: He is seen as suspicious and unreliable, condemned to a perpetual kind of clandestinity.
	•	Paradox of anonymity: Initially, living without documents seems liberating, but it quickly becomes existentially distressing; he cannot fully participate in social life.

Eventually, Mattia must “die a second time” as Adriano Meis and return to his old identity as Mattia Pascal, but he is no longer recognized: his wife has remarried, and his past life has vanished. Trapped in a bureaucratic and identity limbo, he becomes literally “the late Mattia Pascal”: alive in reality, but dead on paper. Pirandello demonstrates how, in a bureaucratic society, the absence of documents, which might seem liberating, actually condemns a person to invisibility and helplessness.

data.title: Biological and Bureaucratic identity
data.desc:
Biological identity: the set of physical and personal characteristics that define a person, such as the body, personal history, passions, and preferences.

Bureaucratic identity: the official identity recognized by the state or institutions, documented through certificates, identity documents, tax codes, passports, registry records, and other administrative acts.

When the two do not coincide, a conflict arises between them, as the person finds themselves in a bureaucratic limbo.
conflitto burocrazia potere

Some people and groups choose to refuse bureaucratic identification, remain anonymous, or avoid administrative control. 
For example, communities like the Amish reject personal photography for religious reasons, and in the USA legal accommodations allow them to stay “anonymous” while still holding valid documents. Asylum seekers sometimes try to avoid fingerprinting in the EURODAC system to prevent automatic transfers under the Dublin mechanism, showing how vulnerable individuals may refuse registration for personal safety. Since the 1960s, some anarchist or “off-grid” communities in the USA and Europe have avoided IDs, health cards, or even birth certificates, which has sometimes prevented children from accessing school or medical care. 
Known cases of “invisible” individuals include Rosa Kuleshova in the USSR, who refused mandatory internal passport registration, John Zerzan in the USA, who wrote about people actively rejecting state bureaucracy, and North American anarcho-primitivist “forest dwellers” who gave up all documents and lived without formal services. 
Those who refuse documents often face severe practical limitations, such as lack of healthcare, work, or housing, forcing many to live on the margins, in isolated communities, or in constant tension with authorities.

data.title: Conflict Between Citizens and Bureaucracy
data.desc:
Although bureaucracy is meant to be a system that maintains order, in the daily lives of citizens it often generates discomfort, frustration, anger, and boredom.

There is a widespread perception and common belief that bureaucracy is long, complex, burdensome, rigid, inaccessible, tedious, and exasperating.

data.title: Wars and struggles linked to bureaucratic borders
data.desc:
Many state borders were bureaucratically drawn at the negotiating table by political leaders, often disregarding the populations living there. This led to conflicts both between states and within nations, as communities did not identify with these imposed boundaries.
	•	India–Pakistan Wars (1947, 1965, 1971) → following the Partition of British India
	•	Arab–Israeli Wars (1948, 1967, 1973) → borders drawn after the British Mandate and UN partition plan
	•	Ethiopia–Eritrea War (1998–2000) → dispute over colonial-era borders
	•	Iraq–Kuwait Conflict / Gulf War (1990–1991) → rooted partly in arbitrary colonial borders in the Middle East
	•	Sudanese Civil Wars (1955–1972, 1983–2005) → borders and ethnic-religious divisions leading to the creation of South Sudan
	•	Yugoslav Wars (1991–2001) → breakup of Yugoslavia along imposed federal boundaries
	•	Somali Civil War (from 1991) → collapse of a state built on colonial borders without regard for clan structures

data.title: concetto di confini tra persone
data.desc: Restrictive orders, such as restraining orders or protection orders, function like material boundaries between people imposed by conflict. They legally limit interactions, define physical or social spaces, and aim to prevent harm. These orders create clear divisions in everyday life, translating interpersonal disputes into structured, enforceable rules.

data.title: humanized bureaucracy
data.desc: To humanize bureaucracy means allowing space for emotions and empathy within administrative processes. It involves introducing compassion, care, and support into interactions with rational rules and procedures. By letting kindness and humanity enter bureaucratic systems, regulations and processes can serve people more effectively, transforming rigid structures into tools that truly respond to human needs.

data.title: Red tape
data.desc:
“Red tape” is an English expression that refers to excessive bureaucracy, official and formal procedures perceived as unnecessary, complex, and causing delays.

One of the most cited definitions is by G. Bozeman:
“Rules, regulations, and procedures that remain in effect and impose a compliance burden on the organization but do not contribute to achieving the functional goals for which the rules were intended.” A Theory of Government Red Tape, 1993

data.title: Apolidi
data.desc:
Individuals who are not recognized as citizens by any state under its laws. This means they lack a nationality and the legal rights that come with it.

Statelessness often arises from the dissolution or partition of states (e.g. breakup of Yugoslavia)

data.title: Terra Nullius
data.desc:
Several territories have existed as “no man’s lands,” disputed between states or left unclaimed due to legal, political, or practical uncertainties. These areas often sparked conflicts but were eventually addressed through bureaucratic practices such as treaties or international negotiations.

Terra Nullius: a Latin term from Roman law meaning “land belonging to no one.” It refers to territories that are not formally under the sovereignty of any state.

Examples
	•	Gornja Siga (on the border between Croatia and Serbia): a disputed area where both countries claim different borders, leaving small pockets of land technically unclaimed.
	•	Bir Tawil (between Egypt and Sudan): a desert territory unclaimed by either country due to conflicting border demarcations.
	•	Marie Byrd Land (in Antarctica): one of the few areas not claimed by any state, partly due to the Antarctic Treaty System.
	•	Palestinian Territories: while not a “terra nullius” in the strict legal sense, the contested status of the land has produced decades of conflict and negotiation, with statehood and sovereignty still unresolved.

data.title: concetto di stato e nazione
data.desc: A state is a political entity with defined territory, a population, and a government exercising sovereignty. A nation is a community united by culture, language, history, or identity. Nations and states do not always match: some nations have no state, and some states contain multiple nations.

data.title: Airport transit, international waters, Antarctica
data.desc: Some places in the world function as shared or “in-between” spaces rather than belonging to a single nation. Airport transit zones create temporary spaces where travelers are between states’ jurisdictions. International waters (the high seas) lie beyond national borders and are regulated by global treaties, open to use by all. Antarctica, under the Antarctic Treaty, is preserved for peaceful purposes and scientific cooperation, with no state allowed to claim sovereignty. These areas illustrate how certain territories are treated as belonging to no one, yet accessible to everyone under shared rules.

Living without citizenship means lacking access to fundamental rights and protections, such as:
	•	Legal identity: difficulty obtaining ID cards, passports, or official documents
	•	Civil rights: exclusion from voting and political participation
	•	Social rights: limited access to healthcare, education, or social services
	•	Work and mobility: inability to work legally, travel abroad, or own property
	•	Legal protection: greater vulnerability to exploitation, detention, or deportation

In practice, many stateless people live in legal and bureaucratic limbo, relying on humanitarian organizations or informal networks, often marginalized within the societies where they reside.

Introducing emotions or personal judgment into this system would compromise its function, because there would be too many variables and ambiguous situations to manage effectively. The strength of bureaucracy lies in its predictability and impartiality, even if this makes it appear rigid or impersonal.

data.title: victims of bureaucratic errors
data.desc: People fall victim to bureaucratic errors when documenting their identity. Mistakes in official records, lost documents, or administrative oversights can create a discrepancy between biological identity and bureaucratic identity, leading to serious consequences such as being unable to access services, travel, or even prove legal existence.
